title-group.article-title: Phytotoxic meroterpenoids with herbicidal activities from the phytopathogenic fungus Pseudopestalotiopsis theae

kwd.tp:taxon-name: Pseudopestalotiopsis theae (Sawada) Maharachch. K.D. Hyde & Crous (Sporocadaceae)
Pestalotiopsis theae (Sawada) Maharachch. K.D. Hyde & Crous (Sporocadaceae)

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Phytotoxic meroterpenoids with herbicidal activities from the phytopathogenic fungus
Pseudopestalotiopsis theae

sec.p:

, Jia-Qi Liu a

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: A R T I C L E I N F O

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p: Phytotoxic meroterpenoids
Herbicidal activity
A B S T R A C T

The fungus Pseudopestalotiopsis theae isolated from the fresh leaves of Illigera celebica , has been reported to be a pathogenic fungus that can cause gray blight on tea leaves, a disease characterized by the appearance of necrotic lesions on tea leaves. The pathogenic substances in this fungus have not been clearly identified. Considering the possible involvement of specialized metabolites in symptom appearance, a chemical investigation of specialized metabolites on
P . theae
was conducted, resulting in the isolation of eight meroterpenoids, including six undescribed biscognienynes G-L and two known ones (biscognienynes B and D). The structures of these new compounds were characterized by extensive NMR spectroscopic and HR-ESI-MS data, and their absolute configurations were elucidated by ECD calculations. Except for biscogniyne L, all the isolated biscognienynes showed different degrees of phytotoxicity to tea in vivo , thereby revealing for the first time the substances in
P. theae
that cause tea gray blight. Inspired by the fact that phytotoxins produced by pathogenic fungus are an effective resource for designing natural and safe bioherbicides, when assayed the herbicidal activity through Petri dish bioassays, biscognienynes G-J showed phytotoxic effects against seed germination and seedling growth of
Setaria viridis
, strongly inhibiting seed germination percentage and radicle and germ lengths of seedlings. The results of this study demonstrated the great potential of biscognienynes G-J to be proposed and developed as ecofriendly herbicides.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: * Corresponding author.

** Corresponding author. Key Laboratory of Medicinal Chemistry for Natural Resource, Ministry of Education , Yunnan Characteristic Plant Extraction Laboratory, Functional Molecules Analysis and Biotransformation Key Laboratory of Universities in Yunnan Province , School of Chemical Science and Technology, Yunnan University, Kunming, 650091, PR China .
E-mail addresses: 1162635732@qq.com (D. Gan), caile@ynu.edu.cn (L. Cai), ztding@ynu.edu.cn (Z.-T. Ding).

Our group has been working on the discovery of structurally interesting and biologically significant natural products from
Illigera celebica Miq. (Hernandiaceae)
and its endophyte (
,
). In the present study, the pathogenic fungus
P. theae
was isolated from the leaves of
I. celebica
, which is associated with tea leaf blight. Although the specialized metabolites of
P. theae
have been reported in the literature (
;
), their phytotoxicity has not been described. Therefore, we have a strong motivation to identify the substances in
P. theae
causing tea gray blight and to search for natural products with potent herbicidal activity. Fermentation of the fungus on potato solid medium yielded eight compounds, including six undescribed meroterpenoids biscognienynes (1–5 and 8) and two known ones (6 and 7) ( Fig. 1 ). Compounds 1–7 exhibited varying degrees of phytotoxicity to tea leaves in vivo . In addition, the herbicidal activities of compounds 1–4 were evaluated through Petri dish bioassays, and the results showed that they showed phytotoxic effects against seed germination and seedling growth of
Setaria viridis
, strongly inhibiting seed germination percentage and radicle and germ lengths of seedlings.

sec.title: 2.1. Structural elucidation
sec.p: Compound 2 was obtained as a yellowish oil and with the molecular formula C 16 H 24 O 4 based on its HR-ESI-MS data, which was in accordance with 1 H, 13 C and DEPT NMR data ((Fig. S9) and showed five degrees of unsaturation. The 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra of 2 were similar to those of 1 except for the presence of a methylene at δ H 1.82 (H-5) and a methine at δ H 2.79 (H-6) instead of the double bond in 1. This assignment was supported by the 1 H– 1 H COSY correlations ( Fig. 2 ) of H-4 ( δ H 3.91)/H 2 -5 ( δ H 1.82)/H-6 ( δ H 2.79)/H-1 ( δ H 3.49). The remaining substructure of 2 was further confirmed by 1 H– 1 H COSY and HMBC correlation analyses ( Fig. 2 ). The relative configuration of 2 was ascertained by examination of its NOESY spectrum ( Fig. 3 ). The NOE correlations of H-1/H-12 and H-3/H-12 indicated that H-1, H-3 and H-12 are β -oriented. In addition, the NOE correlation of H-4 with H-6 indicated that H-4 and H-6 are on the same face. Furthermore, the value of J H-1/H-6 (10.5 Hz) suggested a trans-orientation of these protons, which also indicated that H-4 and H-6 are α -oriented. The aforementioned data supported the existence of two possible enantiomers, (1 R ,2 R ,3 S ,4 R ,6 R )- 2 and (1 S ,2 S ,3 R ,4 S ,6 S )-2. Finally, the absolute configuration of 2 was established as 1 R , 2 R , 3 S , 4 R , 6 R based on the good fit between the calculated and experimental ECD spectra of (1 R ,2 R ,3 S ,4 R ,6 R )-2. 2was named biscognienyne H.

Compound 3 was isolated as a yellowish oil with the molecular formula C 16 H 24 O 6 based on its HRESIMS data. The NMR data ( Table 1 ) of 3 closely resemble those of biscognienyne G (1), indicating that they share the same skeleton. A prominent difference between the spectra of the two compounds was the appearance of peaks corresponding to two additional hydroxy groups at C-9 ( δ C 69.9) and C-10 ( δ C 71.2) in the spectrum of 3. The planar structure of 3 was elucidated by extensive analysis of the 2D NMR spectra ( Fig. 2 ). It was concluded that the core structure of 3 should retain the same stereochemistry as that of the cooccurring 1 based on comparing the corresponding NOE correlations ( Fig. 3 ) and coupling constants and considering the results in conjunction with the biogenesis. However, the configuration of C-9 could not be assigned from the NOESY data. In summary, the possible configurations of 3 were determined to be (1 R ,2 R ,3 S ,4 R ,9 S )-3 and (1 R ,2 R ,3 S ,4 R ,9 R )-3. Finally, the absolute configuration of 3 was determined to be 1 R , 2 R , 3 S , 4 R , 9 S according to the agreement between the experimental spectrum and the calculated spectrum ( Fig. 4 ). Thus, the structure of 3 was revealed and named biscognienyne I.

Compound 4 was isolated as a yellowish oil. The molecular formula of 4 was determined to be C 16 H 24 O 6 by analysis of the positive HR-ESI-MS data. The 1 H and 13 C NMR data ( Table 2 ) of 4 were very similar to those of biscognienyne I (3), indicating that they share the same backbone. The chemical shifts of C-2 ( δ C 63.2) and C-3 ( δ C 61.1) in the spectrum of 4 were significantly upfield of those for the corresponding carbons in the spectrum of 3, indicating the formation of an epoxy unit between the C-2 and C-3 of 4. This conclusion was confirmed by HR-ESI-MS analysis. The planer structure of 4 was further confirmed by analysis of other 2D NMR spectra, including 1 H– 1 H COSY and HMBC spectra ( Fig. 2 ). It was concluded that the chiral carbons of 4 should retain the same properties as those of the cooccurring 3 by comparing the respective chemical shifts, coupling constants and NOE correlations ( Fig. 3 ) in conjunction with the biogenetic characteristics. In addition, this was further confirmed by comparing the experimental and calculated ECD spectra ( Fig. 4 ). Thus, the structure of 4 was revealed and named biscognienyne J.

Compound 5 was also isolated as a yellowish oil. The molecular formula of 5 was determined to be C 16 H 24 O 6 by its HR-ESI-MS data. The 1 H and 13 C NMR data ( Table 2 ) of 5 were very similar to those of 4, except that the oxymethine at δ H 3.30 (m, H-3) and δ H 4.41 (dd, J = 2.5, 3.9 Hz, H-4), as well as the olefinic proton at δ H 5.76 (m, H-5) were significantly shifted to the downfield region in 5 compared to 4, while the chemical shifts of 5 and biscognienyne D (6) [ δ H 3.30 (t, J = 2.5, H-3), δ H 4.43 (dd, J = 2.5, 5.0 Hz, H-4), δ H 5.76 (q, J = 2.4 Hz H-5)] (
) were almost the same at these corresponding positions. This result suggested that the configurations of C-3 and C-4 of 5 and 6 were the same, and 5 was a C-4-epimer of 4. This assignment was further supported by NOE experiment. The NOE correlations ( Fig. 3 ) from H-1 to H-4 and H-12 and from H-3 to H-12 indicated that these protons were on the same face. From a biogenetic point of view, the configuration of C-9 should be the same as that of the 4. Thus, the absolute configuration of 5 was established as 1 R , 2 R , 3 S , 4 S , 9 S . 5 was named biscognienyne K.

Compound 8 was isolated as a colorless gum and had the molecular formula C 16 H 22 O 5 on the basis of the HR-ESI-MS data. The 1 H NMR spectroscopic data ( Table 2 ) displayed signals for four methyl groups [ δ H 1.72, 1.68 (each s, 3H),1.52 and 1.41 (each s, 3H)], two sets of nonequivalent methylene protons [ δ H 2.81 (dd, J = 15.1 and 8.1 Hz, 1H) and δ H 2.36 (dd, J = 15.1 and 6.3 Hz, 1H); δ H 2.65 (d, J = 16.5 Hz, 1H) and δ H 2.50 (d, J = 16.5 Hz, 1H)], three methine protons [ δ H 4.61 (t, J = 2.3 Hz, 1H), δ H 4.23 (t, J = 2.5 Hz, 1H) and δ H 3.85 (t, J = 2.5 Hz, 1H)] and one olefinic proton [ δ H 5.14 (m, 1H)]. The 13 C NMR spectroscopic data ( Table 2 ) showed signals for four methyl carbons ( δ C 27.2, 26.0, 25.1 and 18.3), two methylene carbons ( δ C 29.4 and 47.7), three oxymethine carbons ( δ C 64.0, 66.0 and 68.2), three olefinic quaternary carbons ( δ C 170.3, 136.0 and 111.1), one conjugated ketone carbonyl carbon ( δ C 193.6) and one olefinic methine carbon ( δ C 118.8). A prenyl unit was constructed based on the 1 H– 1 H COSY correlations of H-10/H-9, and the HMBC correlations of H-9 with C-9 and C-11 and those of H 3 -12 and H 3 -13 with C-10 and C-11 ( Fig. 2 ). The 1 H– 1 H COSY correlations of H-6/H-5 and H-7, and the HMBC correlations from H-5 to C-4a and C-8a, from H-6 to C-8 and C-4a, from H-7 to C-8a and C-9, as well as the chemical shifts of C-7, C-8, C-4a and C-8a established a cyclohexene unit with the attachment of the prenyl group at C-8, an epoxy group at C-7 and C-8, and a double bond at C-4a and C-8a. According to the HMBC correlations of H 3 -14 and H 3 -15 to C-2 and C-3, from H-3 to C-2, C-4 and C-4a, and from H-5 to C-4 together with the chemical shifts of C-2 and C-8a, a fused cyclohexene-dihydropyran-4-one was established. In addition, the substituents at C-5 and C-6 were hydroxy groups based on their chemical shifts. The relative configuration was assigned by the NOE data ( Fig. 3 ). The NOE correlations from H-7 to H-5 and H-9 implied that these protons were on the same face. This suggested that there were four possible configurations of 8: 8-(5 S ,6 R ,7 S ,8 S ), 8-(5 R ,6 S ,7 R ,8 R ), 8- (5 S ,6 S ,7 S ,8 S ), 8-(5 R ,6 R ,7 R ,8 R ). Because the experimental ECD data of 8 was similar to the calculated ECD data of 8-(5 S ,6 R ,7 S ,8 S ) isomer ( Fig. 4 ), the absolute configuration of 8 was assigned as 5 S , 6 R , 7 S , 8 S . 8 was named biscognienyne L.

sec.title: 2.2. Determination of phytotoxicity and herbicidal activity
sec.p:
The fungus
P. theae
is a very successful pathogen that can cause tea leaf gray blight and has inflicted enormous losses on tea production (
;
). However, the pathogenic substances in
P. theae
have not been clearly identified. Compounds 1–8 were isolated from
P. theae
and assayed on detached tea leaves at concentrations of 1 mg /mL, and the results are presented in Table 3 . In phytotoxicity bioassay experiments, compounds 1–7 caused severe leaf shrinkage and deformation with necrotic spots, while compound 8 showed no obvious symptoms. However, no phytotoxic symptoms were observed on the leaves that received the negative control treatment. These results indicated that compounds 1–7 exhibited different degrees of phytotoxicity to tea leaves and revealed the substances in
P. theae
causing tea gray blight.

sec.title: 3. Conclusions
sec.p:
In summary, compounds 1–7 isolated from
P. theae
showed varying degrees of phytotoxicity to tea leaves in vivo , and the causative agent of tea gray blight was proposed for the first time. This result not only expanded the knowledge of phytotoxic metabolites produced by
P. theae
, but could facilitate the development of strategies for the disease control, such as genetic modification to improve host resistance and the identification of toxin biosynthesis inhibitors or toxin deactivators (
;
). Moreover, compounds 1–4 showed potential herbicidal activities toward
S. viridis
and could be proposed and developed as natural bioherbicides in order to increase the control of this problematic weed in the future.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: a Measured at 600 MHz. b Measured at 400 MHz.

sec.title: 4.1. General experimental procedures
sec.p: NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker DRX-400. Chemical shifts are expressed in ppm and as CD 3 OD ( δ H 3.31/ δ C 49.0) signals. Optical rotations were determined using a Jasco P-1020 digital polarimeter. Electronic circular dichroism (ECD) spectra were obtained using an Applied Photophysics spectropolarimeter. UV spectra were measured on a Shimadzu UV-2401PC spectrometer. HR-ESI-MS data were acquired on an Agilent 1290 UPLC/6545Q-TOF-MS spectrometer. Column chromatography (CC) was performed using RP-18 (50 μm, Merck, Germany ), Si gel (200–300 mesh, Qingdao Marine Chemical Co. Ltd), and Sephadex LH-20 (GE Chemical Corporation). An Agilent 1260 instrument equipped with a Zorbax SB-C 18 column (5 μm, 9.4 × 250 mm ) was employed for semipreparative HPLC. Thin-layer chromatography (TLC) (GF 254 , Qingdao Ocean Chemical Co. Ltd.) was used to monitor fractions.

sec.title: 4.2. Fungal material and fermentation
sec.p:
The fungus
Pestalotiopsis theae (Sawada) Maharachch. K.D. Hyde & Crous (Sporocadaceae)
was isolated from the fresh leaves of
Illigera celebica Miq. (Hernandiaceae)
collected from Shiping County , Honghe Prefecture , Yunnan Province , China (
102.716 ◦ E
,
24.101 ◦ N
) in
July 2018
. The species was identified as
P. theae
based on its morphological and genetic (ITS) characteristics (GenBank accession No. MW309862 ). The strain was preserved in the School of Chemical Science and Technology , Yunnan University, China
. The strain was maintained on modified PDA medium (1 L of water, 15 g of agar, 20 g of glucose, 200 g of potato, and natural pH) and cultured in a 28 ◦ C constant-temperature incubator for 3 d. Aliquots ( 5 kg ) of potatoes were placed in 50 glass inoculum flasks as a medium, which was then sterilized the medium at 121 ◦ C for 30 min. Finally , the fungi were added to the medium and incubated at room temperature for 30 d.

sec.title: 4.3. Extraction and isolation
sec.p: The fermented potato medium was ultrasonically extracted 3 times for 30 min each time. The extract was concentrated using a rotary evaporator to obtain a final mass of 10 g . The extract was first fractionated by column chromatography using silica gel with a gradient of CHCl 3 –MeOH (100:0 → 30: 1 → 3:1 v / v ) to obtain three fractions (Fr.1- Fr.3). Fr. 1 was passed through a silica gel column with petroleum ether (PE)-EtOAc (30:1 → 3:1 v / v ) to yield 6 ( 3.5 mg ), 7 ( 3.5 mg ) and 8 (6.0 mg). Fr. 2 was separated via a silica gel column ( 250 mm × 25 mm ) washed with CHCl 3 –MeOH (100:1 → 3:1 v / v ) to provide three fractions (Fr. 2–1 to Fr. 2–3). Further separation of Fr. 2-1 by CC over silica gel ( 250 mm × 10 mm ) with PE- EtOAc (20:1 → 3:1 v/v) as the eluent afforded 1 (10.0 mg) and 2 (8.0 mg). Fr. 2-2 was further purified by RP-HPLC with MeCN–H 2 O (1:10 → 1:0 v / v ) to obtain 4 ( 7.5 mg ) and 5 ( 3.5 mg ). Fr. 2–3 was fractionated on a Sephadex LH-20 column eluted with MeOH to yield 3 ( 10.5 mg ).

sec.title: 4.3.1. Biscognienyne G (1)
sec.p: Yellowish oil; [ a ] D : 25.9 ( c = 0.22, MeOH); positive HR-ESI-MS m/ z 301.1409 [M + H] + (calcd for C 16 H 22 O 4 Na + ,301.1410); 1 H and 13 C NMR data see Table 1 .

sec.title: 4.3.5. Biscognienyne K (5)
sec.p: Yellowish oil; [ a ] D 20 : 20.4 ( c = 0.25, MeOH); positive HR-ESI-MS m/ z 317.1359 [M + Na] + (calcd for C 16 H 22 O 5 Na + , 317.1359); 1 H and 13 C NMR data see Table 2 .

sec.title: 4.3.6. Biscognienyne L (8)
sec.p: Colorless gum; [ a ] D : 52.3 ( c = 0.25, MeOH); positive HR-ESI-MS m/z 317.1354 [M + Na] + (calcd for C 16 H 22 O 5 Na + , 317.1359); 1 H and 13 C NMR data see Table 2 .

sec.title: 4.4. Phytotoxicity assay
sec.p:
Phytotoxicity was assessed using the method reported in the literature (
). All the isolated compounds were dissolved in 40 μL of MeOH, to which sterile distilled water (SDW) was added to obtain a volume of 1 mL. The bioassays were conducted at a final concentration of 1 mg /mL for each test sample, after which 0.1 mL of each sample was added to tea leaves. SDW with 4% MeOH was used as a negative control. All experiments were repeated three times.

sec.title: 4.5. Herbicidal activity
sec.p:
The herbicidal activities of compounds 1–4 and 8 were evaluated using a slightly modified the method reported by
. Seeds of
S. viridis
were presterilized with 2% NaOCl for 1 min and washed with distilled water before the experiments. Fifty seeds of
S. viridis
were evenly placed on filter paper and individually placed in sterilized 90 mm Petri dishes. Compounds 1–4 and 8 were diluted in 0.1 mL of MeOH to which 2.4 mL of distilled water was added in order to obtain concentrations of 2 × 10
3 M.
These concentrations were added at 2.5 mL per Petri dish. MeOH at the concentration of 4% in distilled water was also added at 2.5 mL per Petri dish as control. In the experiments, all treatments were replicated three times in a completely randomized design, and all petri dishes were placed in growth chambers (25 ◦ C, dark). Germinated seeds were counted after 5 days, and 5 representative seedlings were selected from each dish to determine radicle and germ length. Seeds were considered germinated when the radicle protruded > 1 mm . All data were presented as the mean ± SD using the Student’ s t -test and one-way ANOVA test for group differences.
P <
0.05 was considered as statistically significant.

sec.title: 4.3.2. Biscognienyne H (2)
sec.p: Yellowish oil; [ a ] D 20 : 46.0 ( c = 0.15, MeOH); positive HR-ESI-MS m/ z 303.1565 [M + H] + (calcd for C 16 H 24 O 4 Na + , 303.1567); 1 H and 13 C NMR data see Table 1 .

sec.title: 4.3.3. Biscognienyne I (3)
sec.p: Yellowish oil; [ a ] D : 40.7 ( c = 0.15, MeOH); positive HR-ESI-MS m/ z 335.1460 [M + Na] + (calcd for C 16 H 24 O 6 Na + , 335.1465); 1 H and 13 C NMR data see Table 1 .

sec.title: 4.3.4. Biscognienyne J (4)
sec.p: Yellowish oil; [ a ] D 20 : 26.1 ( c = 0.10, MeOH); positive HR-ESI-MS m/ z 317.1358 [M + Na] + (calcd for C H O Na + , 317.1359); 1 H and 13 C 16 22 5 NMR data see Table 2.

sec.title: 4.6. ECD calculation
sec.p: Declaration of competing interest
The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.
Data availability
Data will be made available on request.

sec.p: Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi. org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2022.113522.
